description: The oldest park in Minsk, founded in 1805 as the Governor's Garden, making it the first public leisure space in Belarus. Spanning 28 hectares along the Svislach River in the city center, this historic park transformed from an English-style gubernatorial garden into a beloved children's wonderland, complete with a 56-meter Ferris wheel, planetarium, and rich biodiversity including century-old trees.
highlights: 56-meter-high Ferris wheel offering panoramic views of Minsk
Educational observatory and planetarium for stargazing during daytime
Ice Palace indoor skating rink frequented by President Lukashenko
Over 100-year-old trees and rich flora throughout 28 hectares
29 attractions - more than any other park in Minsk
Boat trips on the Svislach River during summer
Small artificial lake with a fairy tale castle
Pony rides for children in summer months
Wildlife including squirrels and ducks that visitors can feed
tips: Visit the Ferris wheel early to avoid long queues - only 4 open booths are available, but closed booths have no queue
Each Ferris wheel revolution takes 10-15 minutes, plenty of time to enjoy the city views
Bring bread or seeds to feed the friendly squirrels and ducks throughout the park
Check if the Ice Palace is open to the public - access is sometimes restricted when President Lukashenko is playing hockey
Visit the restaurant and cafe-conditorium near the main entrance for refreshments
Rent a rowboat or paddle boat on the river for a unique perspective of the park
The park is at its loveliest in summer when outdoor concerts and activities are in full swing
Bring your bike or rent one to explore the well-tended paths
Look for the small Santa Claus house hidden in the park
The park is located right after Victory Square and the State Circus, easy to combine with other sightseeing
vibe: A nostalgic Soviet-era oasis that has gracefully evolved into a vibrant family destination, where locals stroll well-tended paths, children's laughter fills the air, and century-old trees stand witness to over 200 years of history. The atmosphere blends old-world charm with modern entertainment - where dance parties and live bands coexist with quiet contemplation of the stars in the planetarium, and where presidential hockey matches share space with everyday families feeding ducks by the river.
expectations: A typical modern amusement park focused mainly on rides and attractions
A purely children-oriented space with little appeal for adults
A small, compact park given its central location
Standard park fare with basic benches and walking paths
Limited activities beyond the Ferris wheel
reality: Belarus's first-ever public garden with 220 years of rich history dating to 1805
A sophisticated cultural space that hosted poetry evenings and artist plein airs in Soviet times
A sprawling 28-hectare green oasis that expanded after WWII destroyed nearby residential quarters
A biodiverse sanctuary with 100-year-old trees, wildlife, and carefully curated English-style landscaping
29 different attractions plus planetarium, observatory, ice palace, boat rentals, wildlife, and year-round events
unique_facts: The park was founded by Minsk's first governor, Zakhar Korneev, in 1805
Originally designed as Eastern Europe's first public garden in classic English style
President Lukashenko regularly plays ice hockey at the park's Ice Palace
During WWII, destroyed residential quarters allowed the park to expand from 18 to 28 hectares
Among the lost neighborhoods was the house where Belarusian writer Yakub Kolas lived from 1927-1941
The park has had four different names: Governor's Garden, City Park, Profintern Park, and finally Gorky Park in 1936
It only became a dedicated children's park in 1960, over 150 years after its founding
The planetarium and observatory were built specifically when the park received children's park status
Soviet-era covered amphitheater hosted amateur performances, poetry readings, and painting lessons
Has more attractions (29) than any other park in Minsk, including Chelyuskintsev Park's 16
surprises: You can stargaze during the daytime at the educational observatory and planetarium
The park served as an important cultural hub for poetry evenings and art lessons during Soviet times
Access to parts of the park closes when the president is playing hockey at the Ice Palace
The Ferris wheel has both open and closed booths - open ones have long queues but closed ones don't
A small Santa Claus house exists in the park for year-round visits
The fairy tale castle on the artificial lake is currently closed to visitors despite its enchanting appearance
Summer brings lively dance parties with local DJs and live bands, not just quiet strolls
Century-old trees make this park feel more like a botanical garden than a children's playground
The park's expansion came from tragedy - WWII destruction of nearby homes
You can still boat on the same Svislach River where 19th-century governors once strolled
